history.content: It entirely depends on your math background. I know someone that had a lot of experience with math in high school and found CS70 pretty easy with homework taking less than an hour for him each week. Other people (like me) spent many many hours figuring out the material and doing the homework. Are you experienced with proof-writing? Did you do contest math in high school (AMC, AIME, USAMO), that kinda stuff? If so, you'll probably be totally fine. Otherwise, it can be pretty challenging and time-consuming. Main advice is, don't give up or feel discouraged if you're lost/struggling. Persistence is important, keep thinking about whatever you're stuck on and after a good while go ask people (TAs, tutors, professor office hours) for help. Find friends to work together and discuss with (but don't rely on them completely). Good luck!

children.subject: unless you did a substantial amount of competitive math in high school or were exposed to discrete math, i would highly recommend not taking CS70 as your first class at Berkeley, let alone over the summer.
CS70 is not a full time job lol. Again it depends on experience and how comfortable one is with proofs
Your mileage may vary, but both of these numbers sound like overestimates. Over the semester it’s probably 12-15 hours on the high end, and like 2-5 on the low side depending on person.
no way 40 hours a week, extreme overestimate
Over the semester, I would say 20 hours / week for an A. But summer sessions are faster, so 40 hours / week.

history.content:
I'm an incoming freshman, accepted into the EECS major in the CoE. I'm planning on taking CS 70 at Berkeley over the summer. I was wondering what time commitment/workload I should expect to put in to receive an A and any other useful pieces of advice/tips that you guys can give!

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Incoming Freshman summer CS 70
